utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello. I'm Greg Gutfeld with Lisa Boothe, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she once was stranded on a Cheese-it, Dana Perino -- "The Five." Well, stock up on the noisemakers, silly hats and Xanax: The 2020 election is only 838 days away.  A new poll shows that 3 out of 4 Democrats believe it's time for a fresh face. Can you blame them? Check out their ghosts of candidates past: Biden, Hillary, Bernie -- a cross between "The Three Stooges" and "Cocoon." The only way to get out that vote is to deliver walkers door to door while yelling fire.  Biden, he thinks Amtrak is a success. It loses a billion a year. Hillary, everyone loves a rematch, but everyone also loves a winner -- the only thing she's won is ridicule. It's less a rematch and more of remake of "Bride of Chucky." And Bernie, a relic pushing another relic called socialism. He's likable but his beliefs are toxic. He's like those delicious berries you pick that poison your whole tribe.  And we can't forget Liz, can we? But as someone who is 2 percent Native American, I have reservations:

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do. I can say that. I'm Native American, part of me. Not sure what part though. So, Dems want somebody new, somebody different. Where could they have learned this?

utterances.speaker: THEN-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Anthony Weiner, did you know that? She's married to Anthony Weiner, you know, the little bing, bing, bing. I love you very much.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, from the guy they hate so much, that's the hypocrisy. The people who despise Trump are now looking for their own Trump, meaning a punk rock outsider who rejects the establishment and wins. Why? Perhaps we've figured out that the worst things about politics are politicians. And if we learned anything from 2016, it's that nothing will ever be the same. You can't go home again. And if you're a Democrat, that includes retirement homes.   So, yes, they need a new face, especially one that knows the issues. My choice?

utterances.speaker: ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, NEW YORK DEMOCRATIC CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: We need to occupy every airport. We need to occupy every border. We need to occupy every ICE office until those kids are back with their parents.  Capitalism has not always existed in the world and it will not always exist in the world.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You use the term the occupation of Palestine, what do you mean by that?

utterances.speaker: CORTEZ
utterances.sentences: Oh, I think what I meant is like the settlements.  I am not the expert on geopolitics on this issue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Trust me, Democrats. Pick her. You will win in a landslide.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: They might.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, do you agree with me?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that when the Democrat -- every election is about new. This is why we had hope and change.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- right? And the Democrats did go with something new in 2008. They rejected Hillary Clinton and they nominated Barack Obama to be their candidate and he was able to win. And then the Republicans go the other way. They're like, OK, we're going to go with Trump. So now, the Democrats are going to have probably 15 to 17 people on stage fighting it out over the next -- I mean, it's not far away. The midterm election is November 6. The 2020 general election starts November 7.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, if you're really are going to start seeing a lot more of this. And I don't think that necessarily she would win this time around. But the left is becoming more progressive. They want something new and different, somebody who is willing to fight, even if it's futile, right? For example on the Supreme Court nomination. Dan Pfeiffer who is the former communications director for Obama, he's out on his book tour now and he said even though we know we're probably going to lose, it's worth fighting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Fighting to the death. Like, well, you might just fight to the death.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, it's like when you're arguing with a spouse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right, the spouse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, welcome back. You did a great job at the all-star game. I think I have to defend Alexandria. Most people don't know how to explain the Middle East.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: No, and especially if you're 28. I mean, she's a newcomer to the political stage. And forget the geopolitical stage, she's never been on it. I don't think she's gotten there yet. But I think you're exactly right that people want a new face, and it's not only that they want a new face. It's interesting a saw in the polls that there's a split between people who voted for Hillary as to whether or not they would take a Hillary back. Now, I think where the argument you get, Greg, is from the Bernie supporters.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Who see him as Cortez, same thing, more energy. And here's one thing I notice in the research, Democratic strategists say we want somebody who will punch Trump in the face, right? So they want someone who plays like Trump, who's bullying, has the kind of.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: De Niro.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It could be De Niro, right? Yeah, that could be. But I think an actor, a celebrity, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Somebody who brings name I.D. to the table, has pockets of their own money, and challenges the party's base. That sounds like your guys candidate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, there you go. All right, Jesse, I like the idea of a rematch. The reason why I don't think Hillary wants to be forever known as the person who lost to Trump. That's going to be the first line in the obituary, not that she was secretary of state but that she lost to Trump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Twice?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But if she lost again that she lost twice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That would be a great.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I have listened to a lot of, kind of, mediocre and preposterous monologues, but I think that might have been one of your best monologues in a long time. That was very good. Almost as if I wrote it myself. Just kidding. No, I think the Democrats need to nominate a fresh face, and I'm going to be contributing to the campaign coffers of this little socialist, Cortez, whatever her name is. But the Democrats are right when they pull this they want a fresh face. They win with fresh faces. They win with Bill Clinton. They win with Barack Obama. And they lose with Gore and Kerry and Hillary. So, like you've said, they want someone that's gonna punch Trump square in the face. And they don't want to do this Michelle Obama thing where, you know, Trump goes low, we go high. They're ready to get in the mud but there's problems with that. The only person I can see really going toe to toe with him verbally is Biden. And I would not call Biden a fresh face. Also, when you get in the mud with Donald Trump, you never really get out. He's a brawler and he wins ugly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: If he gets to Rubio.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Exactly, that was ugly. And also, he doesn't set up a contrast, a mini-Trump. And I think you win when you set up a nice contrast, but they're having a civil war. And the energy and the idealism is on the far left, and the money and the practicality is more toward the center. And we're going to watch this thing, and it's going to be great to watch. But the media is going to cover up all this internal friction and that's going to be to the detriment of the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: And it's interesting. And it's interesting too because to Dana's point, Democrats used to be really good at sort of sampling primaries and clearing them out. And now they're not as much because you have this progressive wing of the party that is supercharged up. We've seen that come into fruition this primary -- a primary time where we hadn't really seen that before. But I think the bigger problem for Democrats is President Obama had really focused on identity politics for eight years, and with that, you saw a narrowing of the Democratic Party. Republicans were able to take advantage of that during the midterm election. And President Trump was, as well, being able to pick up these Democrat strongholds that hadn't gone for Republican in quite some time. So I think this pushed to the left focusing on things like abolishing ICE only further narrows the party which hurts them and is a negative impact heading into 2020.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, that's the point, actually, Juan, is like -- we talk about this about how Trump wasn't an ideologue. He was some -- some of these stances he had were liberal. Some of them were definitely not Republican. Should the Dems be focusing on somebody who's not an ideological Democrat?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know how we would define an ideological Democrat on the left. I mean, I'm not sure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A communist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A communist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Don't ask a Republican to help you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A Republican will not help you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I was a foolish man to ask that question. You know what I think though, it's interesting, I think the counter to Trump maybe a woman.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Who do you want to see?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A young woman not unlike that one.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Rosie O'Donnell.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no. Like, I think, a young, energetic woman who is unapologetic in saying you know what, yep, I think you should have health care in this country. Yep, I think that we should raise the minimum wage. Yeah, I think that we should have no more student debt for people who are trying to get an education.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Who is this lady, though?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's pretty strong. Well, she's one of them but I think she's too inexperienced.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. How old is she? Go check if she's 35.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Twenty eight, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: To run for president.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah, yeah. That eliminates me too. This contrast thing, large number of Democrats -- Republican candidates that looked alike made Trump standout. We talked about that. So, I think you're going to end up with the Democrat that stands out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right, because a lot of the 15 possible Democrats, a lot of them are senators.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. And it's a hard to run from the senate -- well, Obama did it. But I think McCain and Hillary Clinton showed that it's really hard. OK, a Kerry as well. So, yeah, I'm surprised that his name hasn't surfaced a little bit more. He has a book coming out, September 24th, so you might want to add John Kerry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You planted the seed with Al Franken, and look at what happened with that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Who else you want me to add?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Cross him off the list.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What's interesting is President Trump will have a record to run on, and he will be a known entity to Republicans. He's got right now a 90 percent approval rating among Republicans. So he's running so low and he has a record to run on and a good economy. Then you have this massive primary were really, only 20 percent of the country is saying, OK, we are really far left, 20 percent are saying we're really far right. Now you see in surveys, 60 percent of Americans are saying I'm independent. So what happens, in the primary, you go so far left, to me, that gives President Trump a pretty good opening to walk right back in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Here's where I just think the Democrats face their hardest challenge, when the tea party was ignited, it was based off policy. It was based off of bailouts and Obamacare and spending. And they have these great rallies where they cleaned up after themselves, and they had speakers and then they translated that into winning back the house. And they did all right in the senate. They kind of cut their nose off despite their face a few times. But it translated into electoral success. The Democrats energy, I wouldn't call it at the level of a tea party. I mean, right now, they have small rallies, there's no great speaker, and there basic message is I hate Trump. It's not really around a policy. And the policy that it is around is either abolishing ICE or we want socialism, and their tactics have backfired, chasing people out of restaurants, yelling horrible things at people. I just don't know if they're ready for prime time in terms of fielding good candidates to take back the house.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Also, when you have a crowded primary field, you can see a lot of these people that are being discussed, like a Kamala Harris, a Cory Booker, they all kind of occupy the same space. You could inevitably see someone come down the middle like Trump did, President Trump did, that nobody saw coming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Peter Strzok.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I think the one thing that's not in the equation as you've drawn it is this -- the tremendous energy on the left because of Trump, and I think that now extends to the middle. You see that in the polls, Jesse. The intensity on the left going into the midterms far exceeds what you're seeing on the right, even with something like Kavanaugh, and certainly when it comes to taxes, I don't know what the Republican message is other than we don't like immigrants.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Jobs, economy, winning.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And I said it's 838 days away. It's actually about -- I mean, 20 -- where are we now? 2019 is where it's going to start.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: It's kind of scary that it's so soon.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It starts in 2018.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Starts right now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly. All right. Democrats and the media double down on their extreme reaction to President Trump's summit meeting with Vladimir Putin. Are they playing directly into Russia's hands?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Anti-Trump critics are unveiling a new conspiratorial line of attack against the president. But is this playing into Russia's hands? You decide.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Trumps eagerness to sell out America proves the Russians must have something personally, politically, or financially on President Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Millions of Americans are left wondering if Putin indeed has something over the president.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The way he behaves, there is a clear signal that the Russians have something on him.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: My question is, what is Putin have on Trump?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, President Trump is defending his record on Russia while facing new questions about election meddling from the media.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Is Russia still targeting the U.S., Mr. President?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much. We're doing very well, probably as well as anybody has ever done with Russia. And there's been no president ever as tough as I have been on Russia. All you have to do is look at the numbers. Look at what we've done. Look at sanctions. Look at ambassadors not there. Look, unfortunately, at what happened in Syria recently. And I think President Putin knows that better than anybody, certainly a lot better than the media. He understands it, and he's not happy about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So White House is saying President Trump responded no to answering reporter's questions, not in regards to Russia's attempts to interfere in the midterm elections. All right, Juan, you haven't been here for the last few days. Thank goodness. I know you have been chomping at the bit here to talk about all this Helsinki chaos. Why don't you go ahead?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, no, I think the first thing we should talk about, Jesse, is this idea that he's compromised, that they have something on him, because this is all over now. I mean, when you hear Leon Panetta, and I think Leon Panetta is widely respected across the political divide in our polarized country, say, hey, you know his behavior is mighty peculiar. And it's not explained except by the idea that somehow somebody has some leverage over him, whether it's the notorious tape or money or finances. So today I noticed a lot of pickup on the idea that congress could say, hey, let us see your tax returns, Mr. President. Let's just get this out of the way so we know that you're not somehow financially, you know, in debt to the Russians.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan says, Dana, that it has to be something that the Russians have on Trump to explain his behavior. Couldn't you also say, you know, Trump's not living in a cold war world anymore, and he honestly thinks his outreach to the Russians is just going to make the world a better and safer place.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You could say a lot of things. I do wonder if the Democrats have somehow some poll tested information because you can see when like the bat signal goes out and they all use the same language. I mean, Republicans do that too. But in this case, they were really focused. Just last week when Brett Kavanaugh was nominated to the Supreme Court, a week ago today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What do they say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . it was all about health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Remember we've talked about, oh, the Democrats are zeroing in on the message. They're going to run on health care going into the midterms and it changes all of a sudden. And I wonder if some sort of overnight polling had came in and said you know what really energizes the base, it's not health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's Russia. So they're just going to focus on this writ large. I do think that the question being isn't this what Russia wants, meaning all the chaos within here. I think what Russia really wants is -- well, Putin wants to reconstitute the USSR. He wants power, prestige. He wants to be seen as a big global leader. He was doing poorly in his country because of the economic conditions. When he invaded Crimea, his poll numbers went way up. Well, that started to go down because one of the things they have a huge problem with is their economy. Putin has suggested raising the retirement age. He went from a 68 percent approval rating in March to down to 49 percent now. And that doesn't have to do with President Putin. That's a domestic politics. And every leader takes their own domestic politics to the world stage, and President Trump did too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What do you think about that? Do you think this, you know, traitor talk and they have something on him talk is playing into Russia's hands?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do love the traitor talk because only on CNN is Trump a hard- core nationalist who would then betray his country. I mean, there're so many contradictions in this that he's an appeaser to Putin, yet he's trying to take the pipeline away from him. It's amazing to me. I have an alternative explanation. I look at Trump's behavior as somebody who didn't see what he did wrong, and it is so obvious. His reaction to the reaction was like, what did I do? This is just what I do. I've been talking about this for two years about working with people, working with Russia, might make a better world if you know for prosperity and peace if you work with these people. In his head, it is a business transaction. What he's doing is what -- I've got to build this casino in Atlantic City. I've got to go talk to Sammy, the bull, so I can make sure everything goes well. He sees Putin as this -- a little player that you grease so you can get the things that you need. The problem is this little player, Putin, happens to be involved in a lot of things.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Interference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, interference.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Interference, Middle East, Iran, North Korea. He could help with all of those things. So what he's doing is, OK, I'm going to give Putin a little bit of stature, a little bit of status. In return, he might be able to help us with all of those things. That's a transaction. And that's why he doesn't see it as anything wrong and, frankly, neither do I.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, yeah, he's a businessman and he's not steeped in this kind of cold war mentality where everybody in Washington understands we've been fighting the Russians for decade after decade and we can't ever be nice to them. Trump comes in with a slap on the back and a handshake and just blows the whole system up.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Well, the irony is that President Trump's policies have been tougher than President Obama, so it's sort of ironic that we're at this point we're having these discussions. But I think a lot of people want to look at Russia for sewing the divisions in the country, but we're the ones doing that as a country. We've seen so much division and so much divisiveness over the last few years, and we as Americans are responsible for that. So I think we should probably look at ourselves and want to change that. And also.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can I say one thing about the Democrats, though. I mean, they do feel slighted by Russia for the interference in the election, and they see that the president isn't standing up for election integrity writ large.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That is part of the division. That's not -- they don't have the responsibility to say, OK, rabbi, OK, no problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Get over it. They didn't cause Hillary to lose. Hillary lost.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, they did.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I'd like to finish my points. But, alternatively, you also look at something like Democrats pushing for faceless electors. I think that does a lot more to hurt the electoral process and for people to lose faith in elections, because what is the point in voting if we're going to have faceless electors and Democrats were pushing for that. And quite frankly, that does a lot more to hurt the process than $2,000 spent on social media.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let me ask Juan -- let me ask you a question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do you really think there're some embarrassing emails about Hillary, and Baba, and Chelsea's wedding, swung the election away from Hillary Clinton? You really do think though?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The last ten days -- the Comey stuff with the Weiner emails, I think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, Hillary is responsible for that. She's the one that soak the server.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, she did not. Comey is the one who decided. But let me just say, the news of today is to me was, because I love my colleagues on "The Five," when Trump says that people of higher and intellect understand what he's up to. That's why I came back to the show because I figured I'd be surrounded by people. But I must say, how can you guys not -- you're focusing on, oh, the Democrats -- this guy is saying, oh, no, Russians aren't interfering, contradicting our own intelligence, our own senate. I mean, it's like he's not on our team. He's working for the other team. How can you ignore this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We're not ignoring it. We're talking about it. And at least he didn't bow to the Saudi king.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, get out of here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Are designer babies coming to America? The controversy up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A major moral and scientific debate is heating up after a landmark decision in the U.K. where the leading ethics counsel there has given the go-ahead to genetically modified babies. In other words, parents could predetermine the DNA, including physical attributes of their future children. In the lab, the Guardian reporting, quote, the U.K. Muffield Council on bioethics says changing the DNA of a human embryo could be morally permissible if it is in the child's best interests. Critics worry the technology could be misused to create a genetic elite. Greg, this is not a new topic. It might be new that the U.K. is making a formal decision, but like this has been going on for quite a while.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And as far as I can see so far, it's mostly to try to prevent illnesses and disease.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, critics of new technology are almost always wrong.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They always go, oh, my God. Something bad is going to happen. And they do science no favors. If you have the chance to eliminate or reduce the certainty of certain life-long medical disorders among children, genetic modification could prevent that problem. These are gene therapies. And, by the way, when a pregnant woman goes on supplements, or quit smoking, or reduces alcohol, she's designing the baby too. When you read to your child, when you introduce discipline and certain kind of moral precepts, you're designing a child. If anything, we need more design than ever. I've seen these kids.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: that could be a controversial way to look at it. Jesse, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS,
utterances.sentences: Listen, I think in 100 years, anyone who has money is going to have a designer baby to a certain extent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Going to be a little Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, perfection embodies. And you know, they're going to say -- they tinker with the genome. A little bit taller, a little better looking, a little smarter, funnier. And -- and that's how it's going to be, because everybody wants to play God. All humans want to play God, especially if you're rich. You want to play God. I don't know if I would do it. I like to roll the dice, you know. But I mean, if you can get a lock, and you can afford a lock, I don't see why people wouldn't do it. I don't know if America is ready for it, though.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: The problem is, they're not God. And I come from this from a personal approach in the sense that I have an aunt who's special-needs and a little brother with Asperger's. And these are the types of people that folks would try to avoid having. So I look at this from a personal lens in the sense that my aunt is the wisest person I've ever met. My little brother is the most warmhearted, one of the smartest people I've ever met. And I can't imagine a life or a world without them. And quite frankly, I think we have more to learn from individuals with special needs in this country than they have from us. So I fully oppose this, and I look at it similar to what countries like Iceland are doing, with avoiding babies with Down syndrome and trying to essentially eliminate kids with Down syndrome, and I find it disgusting. And I look at this from a purely -- a purely personal standpoint.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How do you feel about, like, cochlear implants, which allows the deaf to hear?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS,

utterances.sentences: That it's not new. This is -- these studies are consistent over time. And I -- I don't know. I grew up in a pretty conservative world in Wyoming and Colorado. utterances.sentences: Yet. And I'm pretty happy. But I do think -- I think Dana, you made really good points. And I think the religion part of it, one aspect. And so I think when you have that sort of mentality, of "if I want something, if I want to do better life, I'm going to accomplish it on my own." utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.sentences: OK.

The only way to get out that vote is to deliver walkers door to door while yelling fire. Biden, he thinks Amtrak is a success. It loses a billion a year. Hillary, everyone loves a rematch, but everyone also loves a winner -- the only thing she's won is ridicule. It's less a rematch and more of remake of "Bride of Chucky." And Bernie, a relic pushing another relic called socialism. He's likable but his beliefs are toxic. He's like those delicious berries you pick that poison your whole tribe. And we can't forget Liz, can we? But as someone who is 2 percent Native American, I have reservations:

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do. I can say that. I'm Native American, part of me. Not sure what part though. So, Dems want somebody new, somebody different. Where could they have learned this?

utterances.speaker: THEN-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Anthony Weiner, did you know that? She's married to Anthony Weiner, you know, the little bing, bing, bing. I love you very much.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, from the guy they hate so much, that's the hypocrisy. The people who despise Trump are now looking for their own Trump, meaning a punk rock outsider who rejects the establishment and wins. Why? Perhaps we've figured out that the worst things about politics are politicians. And if we learned anything from 2016, it's that nothing will ever be the same. You can't go home again. And if you're a Democrat, that includes retirement homes. So, yes, they need a new face, especially one that knows the issues. My choice?

utterances.speaker: ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, NEW YORK DEMOCRATIC CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: We need to occupy every airport. We need to occupy every border. We need to occupy every ICE office until those kids are back with their parents. Capitalism has not always existed in the world and it will not always exist in the world.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You use the term the occupation of Palestine, what do you mean by that?

utterances.speaker: CORTEZ
utterances.utterance: Oh, I think what I meant is like the settlements. I am not the expert on geopolitics on this issue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Trust me, Democrats. Pick her. You will win in a landslide.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: They might.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, do you agree with me?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that when the Democrat -- every election is about new. This is why we had hope and change.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- right? And the Democrats did go with something new in 2008. They rejected Hillary Clinton and they nominated Barack Obama to be their candidate and he was able to win. And then the Republicans go the other way. They're like, OK, we're going to go with Trump. So now, the Democrats are going to have probably 15 to 17 people on stage fighting it out over the next -- I mean, it's not far away. The midterm election is November 6. The 2020 general election starts November 7.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, if you're really are going to start seeing a lot more of this. And I don't think that necessarily she would win this time around. But the left is becoming more progressive. They want something new and different, somebody who is willing to fight, even if it's futile, right? For example on the Supreme Court nomination. Dan Pfeiffer who is the former communications director for Obama, he's out on his book tour now and he said even though we know we're probably going to lose, it's worth fighting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fighting to the death. Like, well, you might just fight to the death.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it's like when you're arguing with a spouse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right, the spouse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan, welcome back. You did a great job at the all-star game. I think I have to defend Alexandria. Most people don't know how to explain the Middle East.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No, and especially if you're 28. I mean, she's a newcomer to the political stage. And forget the geopolitical stage, she's never been on it. I don't think she's gotten there yet. But I think you're exactly right that people want a new face, and it's not only that they want a new face. It's interesting a saw in the polls that there's a split between people who voted for Hillary as to whether or not they would take a Hillary back. Now, I think where the argument you get, Greg, is from the Bernie supporters.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who see him as Cortez, same thing, more energy. And here's one thing I notice in the research, Democratic strategists say we want somebody who will punch Trump in the face, right? So they want someone who plays like Trump, who's bullying, has the kind of.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: De Niro.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It could be De Niro, right? Yeah, that could be. But I think an actor, a celebrity, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Somebody who brings name I.D. to the table, has pockets of their own money, and challenges the party's base. That sounds like your guys candidate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, there you go. All right, Jesse, I like the idea of a rematch. The reason why I don't think Hillary wants to be forever known as the person who lost to Trump. That's going to be the first line in the obituary, not that she was secretary of state but that she lost to Trump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Twice?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But if she lost again that she lost twice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That would be a great.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I have listened to a lot of, kind of, mediocre and preposterous monologues, but I think that might have been one of your best monologues in a long time. That was very good. Almost as if I wrote it myself. Just kidding. No, I think the Democrats need to nominate a fresh face, and I'm going to be contributing to the campaign coffers of this little socialist, Cortez, whatever her name is. But the Democrats are right when they pull this they want a fresh face. They win with fresh faces. They win with Bill Clinton. They win with Barack Obama. And they lose with Gore and Kerry and Hillary. So, like you've said, they want someone that's gonna punch Trump square in the face. And they don't want to do this Michelle Obama thing where, you know, Trump goes low, we go high. They're ready to get in the mud but there's problems with that. The only person I can see really going toe to toe with him verbally is Biden. And I would not call Biden a fresh face. Also, when you get in the mud with Donald Trump, you never really get out. He's a brawler and he wins ugly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If he gets to Rubio.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly, that was ugly. And also, he doesn't set up a contrast, a mini-Trump. And I think you win when you set up a nice contrast, but they're having a civil war. And the energy and the idealism is on the far left, and the money and the practicality is more toward the center. And we're going to watch this thing, and it's going to be great to watch. But the media is going to cover up all this internal friction and that's going to be to the detriment of the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: And it's interesting. And it's interesting too because to Dana's point, Democrats used to be really good at sort of sampling primaries and clearing them out. And now they're not as much because you have this progressive wing of the party that is supercharged up. We've seen that come into fruition this primary -- a primary time where we hadn't really seen that before. But I think the bigger problem for Democrats is President Obama had really focused on identity politics for eight years, and with that, you saw a narrowing of the Democratic Party. Republicans were able to take advantage of that during the midterm election. And President Trump was, as well, being able to pick up these Democrat strongholds that hadn't gone for Republican in quite some time. So I think this pushed to the left focusing on things like abolishing ICE only further narrows the party which hurts them and is a negative impact heading into 2020.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, that's the point, actually, Juan, is like -- we talk about this about how Trump wasn't an ideologue. He was some -- some of these stances he had were liberal. Some of them were definitely not Republican. Should the Dems be focusing on somebody who's not an ideological Democrat?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know how we would define an ideological Democrat on the left. I mean, I'm not sure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A communist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A communist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't ask a Republican to help you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A Republican will not help you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I was a foolish man to ask that question. You know what I think though, it's interesting, I think the counter to Trump maybe a woman.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Who do you want to see?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A young woman not unlike that one.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Rosie O'Donnell.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. Like, I think, a young, energetic woman who is unapologetic in saying you know what, yep, I think you should have health care in this country. Yep, I think that we should raise the minimum wage. Yeah, I think that we should have no more student debt for people who are trying to get an education.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Who is this lady, though?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's pretty strong. Well, she's one of them but I think she's too inexperienced.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. How old is she? Go check if she's 35.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Twenty eight, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: To run for president.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, yeah. That eliminates me too. This contrast thing, large number of Democrats -- Republican candidates that looked alike made Trump standout. We talked about that. So, I think you're going to end up with the Democrat that stands out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right, because a lot of the 15 possible Democrats, a lot of them are senators.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. And it's a hard to run from the senate -- well, Obama did it. But I think McCain and Hillary Clinton showed that it's really hard. OK, a Kerry as well. So, yeah, I'm surprised that his name hasn't surfaced a little bit more. He has a book coming out, September 24th, so you might want to add John Kerry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You planted the seed with Al Franken, and look at what happened with that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Who else you want me to add?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Cross him off the list.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What's interesting is President Trump will have a record to run on, and he will be a known entity to Republicans. He's got right now a 90 percent approval rating among Republicans. So he's running so low and he has a record to run on and a good economy. Then you have this massive primary were really, only 20 percent of the country is saying, OK, we are really far left, 20 percent are saying we're really far right. Now you see in surveys, 60 percent of Americans are saying I'm independent. So what happens, in the primary, you go so far left, to me, that gives President Trump a pretty good opening to walk right back in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here's where I just think the Democrats face their hardest challenge, when the tea party was ignited, it was based off policy. It was based off of bailouts and Obamacare and spending. And they have these great rallies where they cleaned up after themselves, and they had speakers and then they translated that into winning back the house. And they did all right in the senate. They kind of cut their nose off despite their face a few times. But it translated into electoral success. The Democrats energy, I wouldn't call it at the level of a tea party. I mean, right now, they have small rallies, there's no great speaker, and there basic message is I hate Trump. It's not really around a policy. And the policy that it is around is either abolishing ICE or we want socialism, and their tactics have backfired, chasing people out of restaurants, yelling horrible things at people. I just don't know if they're ready for prime time in terms of fielding good candidates to take back the house.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Also, when you have a crowded primary field, you can see a lot of these people that are being discussed, like a Kamala Harris, a Cory Booker, they all kind of occupy the same space. You could inevitably see someone come down the middle like Trump did, President Trump did, that nobody saw coming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Peter Strzok.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think the one thing that's not in the equation as you've drawn it is this -- the tremendous energy on the left because of Trump, and I think that now extends to the middle. You see that in the polls, Jesse. The intensity on the left going into the midterms far exceeds what you're seeing on the right, even with something like Kavanaugh, and certainly when it comes to taxes, I don't know what the Republican message is other than we don't like immigrants.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Jobs, economy, winning.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And I said it's 838 days away. It's actually about -- I mean, 20 -- where are we now? 2019 is where it's going to start.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: It's kind of scary that it's so soon.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It starts in 2018.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Starts right now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly. All right. Democrats and the media double down on their extreme reaction to President Trump's summit meeting with Vladimir Putin. Are they playing directly into Russia's hands?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Anti-Trump critics are unveiling a new conspiratorial line of attack against the president. But is this playing into Russia's hands? You decide.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Trumps eagerness to sell out America proves the Russians must have something personally, politically, or financially on President Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Millions of Americans are left wondering if Putin indeed has something over the president.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The way he behaves, there is a clear signal that the Russians have something on him.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: My question is, what is Putin have on Trump?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, President Trump is defending his record on Russia while facing new questions about election meddling from the media.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.utterance: Is Russia still targeting the U.S., Mr. President?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much. We're doing very well, probably as well as anybody has ever done with Russia. And there's been no president ever as tough as I have been on Russia. All you have to do is look at the numbers. Look at what we've done. Look at sanctions. Look at ambassadors not there. Look, unfortunately, at what happened in Syria recently. And I think President Putin knows that better than anybody, certainly a lot better than the media. He understands it, and he's not happy about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So White House is saying President Trump responded no to answering reporter's questions, not in regards to Russia's attempts to interfere in the midterm elections. All right, Juan, you haven't been here for the last few days. Thank goodness. I know you have been chomping at the bit here to talk about all this Helsinki chaos. Why don't you go ahead?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, no, I think the first thing we should talk about, Jesse, is this idea that he's compromised, that they have something on him, because this is all over now. I mean, when you hear Leon Panetta, and I think Leon Panetta is widely respected across the political divide in our polarized country, say, hey, you know his behavior is mighty peculiar. And it's not explained except by the idea that somehow somebody has some leverage over him, whether it's the notorious tape or money or finances. So today I noticed a lot of pickup on the idea that congress could say, hey, let us see your tax returns, Mr. President. Let's just get this out of the way so we know that you're not somehow financially, you know, in debt to the Russians.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan says, Dana, that it has to be something that the Russians have on Trump to explain his behavior. Couldn't you also say, you know, Trump's not living in a cold war world anymore, and he honestly thinks his outreach to the Russians is just going to make the world a better and safer place.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You could say a lot of things. I do wonder if the Democrats have somehow some poll tested information because you can see when like the bat signal goes out and they all use the same language. I mean, Republicans do that too. But in this case, they were really focused. Just last week when Brett Kavanaugh was nominated to the Supreme Court, a week ago today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do they say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . it was all about health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember we've talked about, oh, the Democrats are zeroing in on the message. They're going to run on health care going into the midterms and it changes all of a sudden. And I wonder if some sort of overnight polling had came in and said you know what really energizes the base, it's not health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's Russia. So they're just going to focus on this writ large. I do think that the question being isn't this what Russia wants, meaning all the chaos within here. I think what Russia really wants is -- well, Putin wants to reconstitute the USSR. He wants power, prestige. He wants to be seen as a big global leader. He was doing poorly in his country because of the economic conditions. When he invaded Crimea, his poll numbers went way up. Well, that started to go down because one of the things they have a huge problem with is their economy. Putin has suggested raising the retirement age. He went from a 68 percent approval rating in March to down to 49 percent now. And that doesn't have to do with President Putin. That's a domestic politics. And every leader takes their own domestic politics to the world stage, and President Trump did too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you think about that? Do you think this, you know, traitor talk and they have something on him talk is playing into Russia's hands?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do love the traitor talk because only on CNN is Trump a hard- core nationalist who would then betray his country. I mean, there're so many contradictions in this that he's an appeaser to Putin, yet he's trying to take the pipeline away from him. It's amazing to me. I have an alternative explanation. I look at Trump's behavior as somebody who didn't see what he did wrong, and it is so obvious. His reaction to the reaction was like, what did I do? This is just what I do. I've been talking about this for two years about working with people, working with Russia, might make a better world if you know for prosperity and peace if you work with these people. In his head, it is a business transaction. What he's doing is what -- I've got to build this casino in Atlantic City. I've got to go talk to Sammy, the bull, so I can make sure everything goes well. He sees Putin as this -- a little player that you grease so you can get the things that you need. The problem is this little player, Putin, happens to be involved in a lot of things.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Interference.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, interference.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Interference, Middle East, Iran, North Korea. He could help with all of those things. So what he's doing is, OK, I'm going to give Putin a little bit of stature, a little bit of status. In return, he might be able to help us with all of those things. That's a transaction. And that's why he doesn't see it as anything wrong and, frankly, neither do I.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, yeah, he's a businessman and he's not steeped in this kind of cold war mentality where everybody in Washington understands we've been fighting the Russians for decade after decade and we can't ever be nice to them. Trump comes in with a slap on the back and a handshake and just blows the whole system up.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, the irony is that President Trump's policies have been tougher than President Obama, so it's sort of ironic that we're at this point we're having these discussions. But I think a lot of people want to look at Russia for sewing the divisions in the country, but we're the ones doing that as a country. We've seen so much division and so much divisiveness over the last few years, and we as Americans are responsible for that. So I think we should probably look at ourselves and want to change that. And also.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I say one thing about the Democrats, though. I mean, they do feel slighted by Russia for the interference in the election, and they see that the president isn't standing up for election integrity writ large.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That is part of the division. That's not -- they don't have the responsibility to say, OK, rabbi, OK, no problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Get over it. They didn't cause Hillary to lose. Hillary lost.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they did.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I'd like to finish my points. But, alternatively, you also look at something like Democrats pushing for faceless electors. I think that does a lot more to hurt the electoral process and for people to lose faith in elections, because what is the point in voting if we're going to have faceless electors and Democrats were pushing for that. And quite frankly, that does a lot more to hurt the process than $2,000 spent on social media.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let me ask Juan -- let me ask you a question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you really think there're some embarrassing emails about Hillary, and Baba, and Chelsea's wedding, swung the election away from Hillary Clinton? You really do think though?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The last ten days -- the Comey stuff with the Weiner emails, I think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, Hillary is responsible for that. She's the one that soak the server.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, she did not. Comey is the one who decided. But let me just say, the news of today is to me was, because I love my colleagues on "The Five," when Trump says that people of higher and intellect understand what he's up to. That's why I came back to the show because I figured I'd be surrounded by people. But I must say, how can you guys not -- you're focusing on, oh, the Democrats -- this guy is saying, oh, no, Russians aren't interfering, contradicting our own intelligence, our own senate. I mean, it's like he's not on our team. He's working for the other team. How can you ignore this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're not ignoring it. We're talking about it. And at least he didn't bow to the Saudi king.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, get out of here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are designer babies coming to America? The controversy up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A major moral and scientific debate is heating up after a landmark decision in the U.K. where the leading ethics counsel there has given the go-ahead to genetically modified babies. In other words, parents could predetermine the DNA, including physical attributes of their future children. In the lab, the Guardian reporting, quote, the U.K. Muffield Council on bioethics says changing the DNA of a human embryo could be morally permissible if it is in the child's best interests. Critics worry the technology could be misused to create a genetic elite. Greg, this is not a new topic. It might be new that the U.K. is making a formal decision, but like this has been going on for quite a while.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And as far as I can see so far, it's mostly to try to prevent illnesses and disease.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, critics of new technology are almost always wrong.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They always go, oh, my God. Something bad is going to happen. And they do science no favors. If you have the chance to eliminate or reduce the certainty of certain life-long medical disorders among children, genetic modification could prevent that problem. These are gene therapies. And, by the way, when a pregnant woman goes on supplements, or quit smoking, or reduces alcohol, she's designing the baby too. When you read to your child, when you introduce discipline and certain kind of moral precepts, you're designing a child. If anything, we need more design than ever. I've seen these kids.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: that could be a controversial way to look at it. Jesse, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS,
utterances.utterance: Listen, I think in 100 years, anyone who has money is going to have a designer baby to a certain extent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Going to be a little Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, perfection embodies. And you know, they're going to say -- they tinker with the genome. A little bit taller, a little better looking, a little smarter, funnier. And -- and that's how it's going to be, because everybody wants to play God. All humans want to play God, especially if you're rich. You want to play God. I don't know if I would do it. I like to roll the dice, you know. But I mean, if you can get a lock, and you can afford a lock, I don't see why people wouldn't do it. I don't know if America is ready for it, though.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: The problem is, they're not God. And I come from this from a personal approach in the sense that I have an aunt who's special-needs and a little brother with Asperger's. And these are the types of people that folks would try to avoid having. So I look at this from a personal lens in the sense that my aunt is the wisest person I've ever met. My little brother is the most warmhearted, one of the smartest people I've ever met. And I can't imagine a life or a world without them. And quite frankly, I think we have more to learn from individuals with special needs in this country than they have from us. So I fully oppose this, and I look at it similar to what countries like Iceland are doing, with avoiding babies with Down syndrome and trying to essentially eliminate kids with Down syndrome, and I find it disgusting. And I look at this from a purely -- a purely personal standpoint.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How do you feel about, like, cochlear implants, which allows the deaf to hear?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But I think what you're looking at with this is you're -- who gets to make the kind of decisions about what sort of genes and defects, quote unquote, "defects" that we're making?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The parents. So instance, like, theoretically, if you see that the child has some sort of abnormality and you can go into a lab with a doctor and say, "Maybe if I can tweak a gene," and then the child does not have that abnormality, the parents are getting an opportunity to make that decision. Is that what this is about?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS,
utterances.utterance: That's if, for example, in the case that we're discussing, the one that the British approved, it had to do with a heart problem. Right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And that was specific.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Now, what they say is that most of the things, like if you say, "I want to be more like Jesse Watters. I want to be more athletic."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No one wants that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They don't?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll let Mrs. Watters respond.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Jesse supports this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But they don't know how to quite do that yet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This technology, invented in the U.S. But guess who is specializing and pushing it? The Chinese.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And they have, you know, they used to have the one child policy and the like. This does not bode well. So what you get is, to me, and speaking as an American, is a worry about inequities, because it seems to me, just like, you know, the children of the rich have a higher chance of getting into Harvard, Yale and Princeton. Guess what? The children of the rich are the ones who would benefit from genetic engineering of some type.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Let me ask Greg something.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They'd become, like, a super race of paper.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But also, Greg, also -- often when there is a new technology, the ethical concerns and the legislation or the regulation always lags. And so isn't it too late to have this discussion?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think it is. And I think going back to the case that Juan brings up. I think it is about stuff like that. I think it's not about making Jesse Watters a new -- a better Jesse Watters, if that's possible. But the reason why I bring up the cochlear implants is there is a movement of people who believe that you're eliminating deaf culture. So that actual cochlear implants, which allow you to hear, is actually a bad thing. And it's like, well, who's to judge that? If a parent wants their child to hear for the first time, and they're activists saying, "No," well --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The parents should get to decide.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. I think that's where you end up. And I don't think it's about, like -- you know, and actually, it might actually -- it might reduce abortions, because you're -- you're, you know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Able to fix an abnormality maybe?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Anyway, it's a very interesting discussion, and it's certainly not over. Neither are we. Up next, a great political debate. Who's happier, liberals or conservatives? The answer is straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We keep hearing the term Trump Derangement Syndrome. It's thrown around, but is it real? Are liberals really that unhappy with the president? Well, we don't have an answer on that one, folks, but new research does show that conservatives are overall happier, more satisfied, and find greater meaning in life than liberals. What do you make of this, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That it's not new. This is -- these studies are consistent over time. And I -- I don't know. I grew up in a pretty conservative world in Wyoming and Colorado. Well, when Colorado was red. So I think it just might be an outlook on life. And possibly -- and I don't know if this is true anymore. But attending religious services or having faith, I do think that that adds to happiness. But also, conservatives, they're pretty happy with the country. They like the Constitution. They don't think it should be changed. So liberals tend to really want to change all of those things. Like, we're talking about a living Constitution. Like, no, conservatives are quite happy with what we have. And so I think that's probably -- it leads to it. But I'm not exactly sure. Maybe conservatives might have more dogs.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: More dogs. But let me pick up on what Dana was saying, because what the research shows is if you have more money, if you are more likely to be married and have kids, then you're happier.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, I have none of those things.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yet.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yet. And I'm pretty happy. But I do think -- I think Dana, you made really good points. And I think the religion part of it, one aspect. Because if you think that life is about something bigger than you, then you're going to be more outwardly focused, as opposed to inward. And then, two, I think Republicans are very self-reliant in the sense of we believe that we create our own success. We don't look to the government. We don't look, you know, for outside resources to get ahead. And so I think when you have that sort of mentality, of "if I want something, if I want to do better life, I'm going to accomplish it on my own." That would bring a better sense of fulfillment and satisfaction and happiness.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I've got to shock you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It says here that the happiest Americans are either extremely conservative -- that's 48 percent --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- or extremely liberal. That's 35 percent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, that's interesting. Because I was going to say that people who aren't happy are often those who make politics personal. They identify themselves so much to politics. You will never be happy. You have to have -- you have to treat -- but happiness is really weird. Because it's really about long-term satisfaction. And they do these studies, and they find that people are satisfied relative to others. Meaning, like, you could be happy at 5'8". But if all of you were 5'10", I would be unhappy. So it's -- it's status relative. And that's why maybe conservatives might be happier, is that religion helps mitigate the envy and the dissatisfaction that happens with status inequality. If you -- if you don't believe in God -- and I won't say where I am on this because then I'll get letters, but status inequality is unexplained. Like, if you're in a godless society and you can't explain why on Instagram everybody is having a better time than you and you don't have a community and you don't have friends that you can talk to or a higher power, all you have is envy. And I think that's -- that's a very destructive thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Didn't you just do a podcast about this?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I did. Thank you for plugging that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remind me, the guy who wrote it, "The Happiness Project"?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jonathan Rauch [SIC].

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think Greg makes a good point. When I go on Instagram, I get insecure, because everyone's tan and looks great with their shirt off.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So I don't go on there anymore. But here are my theories about why this is the truth.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Was that boys or girls?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Both. Here's what I think. I think liberals see the world through the prism of victimhood and suffering. And so they see all these wrongs that need to be corrected. And it's exhausting, and it's incredibly draining. I also don't think they're as patriotic. So they live in a country that was -- we overran the Indians, and then it was built by slaves. And now greedy corporations are running the show, and that drives them crazy. And then also -- I think studies prove this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And you could be content with this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying that's how they see things.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't see the history of the United States like that. And that also, studies will prove that conservatives are better looking and more financially successful, so that makes liberals, I think, socially feel a little awkward.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, are you happy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That whole Hollywood crowd, you mean those liberals, that are so good looking?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're not happy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, they're miserable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can I disagree with what you said? Can I disagree with one of the points you said?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Studies show that children do not increase satisfaction. That's a fact. It's because they're actually a burden. They're actually harder on your life. And people say, "OH, children will make your life better."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But it says here --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I saw an opposite study.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- 52 percent of married people with kids, very happy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now I'm going to get letters.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I have a niece and she makes me very happy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's because she's your niece, not your kid. If it were your kid, you'd be miserable.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I'll report back in a few years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I've got to tell you, grandkids are like this, too.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: All right. Nowhere near that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I would say quickly that the one -- when I tell people what I think are the keys to happiness: one, get as much as education you have; two, get married before you have kids; and three, keep a job until you can --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You sound like a conservative.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There you go. I don't think that's very conservative. I think that's rational. Find out who on "The Five," yes, among this "Five" brotherhood and sisterhood, would be brave enough to blast off into outer space. You've got to stay right here to find out who it is.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. So have you ever dreamed of taking a trip to space? Well, Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has your ticket to the stars for an out-of- this-world price. For a reported $200,000 per person, a ride aboard his Blue Origin space rocket will give adventurous passengers the chance to experience zero gravity. Putting cost side, who here on "The Five" would be willing to go? Greg, I feel like you would do this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Absolutely not. I have no interest.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: There is no way?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No way in hell. I have problems with the elevators. And I don't trust Bezos. He'd just put you in a box. Robots aren't space. I'm more interested in inner space, what's going on at the subatomic level. Like quantum physics, and the relationship to time and space and your consciousness. There's, like, a lot of speculation in that our consciousness, how we view the world, is based on the sub-particles around us. That's more interesting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That it interesting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like the fact that, if it weren't for these sub particles, we wouldn't --
